subject: Re: [junit] Article That Should Help Testing: "Five Habits of Highly Profitable Software Dev
msgSnippet: ... Again, I agree ... for times when using mutable objects. With immutable objects, these problems fade into the ether and no longer haunt us. There are just
messageBody:
On 8/24/06, Cédric Beust ♔ <cbeust@...> wrote:
> On 8/24/06, Simon Chappell <simonpeterchappell@...> wrote:
> >
> >
> > Point five. I agree up to a point. There will always be some things
> > that need to be done in specific sequences. Opening and closing files
> > leaps to mind at this point.
>
>
> It would also be useful to point out that keeping state between method
> invocations doesn't necessarily mean that these methods cannot be invoked in
> any order: just make sure that this state is read-only. And maintaining
> state that is expensive to create is a fairly common design pattern in
> testing.

Again, I agree ... for times when using mutable objects. With
immutable objects, these problems fade into the ether and no longer
haunt us. There are just too many advantages that come with using
immutable objects; I often wonder why more people don't use them.

Simon

--
www.simonpeter.org
